results.headline: Strange and Soulful Music
results.display_title: Wild Combination: A Portrait of Arthur Russell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Combination: A Portrait of Arthur Russell

results.summary_short: The music of Arthur Russell fused minimalist drone to ethereal melody, cello thrum to warbling vocals, downtown braininess to universal pop.

results.headline: Learning to Be the Future of France

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Class

results.summary_short: The young bodies crowding “The Class,” an artful, intelligent movie, come in all sizes, shapes and colors.

results.headline: Layers of Political Strategy
results.display_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story

results.summary_short: Like a trompe l’oeil painting, “Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story” deftly positions its subject as both the savior of the Republican Party and the Antichrist of American politics.

results.headline: Conflict in Britain

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shoot on Sight

results.summary_short: Marrying small-screen formula to big-screen actors, “Shoot on Sight” is an earnest melodrama that struggles to surmount its good intentions.

results.headline: Making Cosmic Waves

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ripple Effect

results.summary_short: “Ripple Effect” starts with a not-very-original insight and takes too many shortcuts delivering it.

results.headline: Classically Dirty

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Obscene

results.summary_short: Without Barney Rosset, you might never have been able to hide that copy of “Lady Chatterley’s Lover” from your parents.

results.headline: Sports Therapy
results.byline: By JEANNETTE CATSOULIS NATHAN LEE  NEIL GENZLINGER   LAURA KERN

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forever Strong

results.summary_short: “Forever Strong” was devised by committee, plotted by machine and acted on cruise control.

results.headline: Big Storm Is Brewing (Hurricane, Too)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nights in Rodanthe

results.summary_short: There’s no joy and not even much cruel laughter to be had from “Nights in Rodanthe.”

results.headline: Tales of a Filipino Ladyboy
results.display_title: The Amazing Truth About Queen Raquela

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Amazing Truth About Queen Raquela

results.summary_short: Those already attuned to the transgendered world will certainly find “The Amazing Truth About Queen Raquela” to be a heartfelt, unusual take on it.

results.headline: Hollywood War, Revised Edition

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miracle at St. Anna

results.summary_short: “Miracle at St. Anna” exists in part to make the overdue point that African-American soldiers fought as bravely and as hard as the characters in Hollywood combat epics.

results.headline: Surprises and Epiphanies for Soldiers on a Road Trip

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lucky Ones

results.summary_short: With a smooth, light touch, “The Lucky Ones” focuses on the idea that the present and the people who factor into it are all we really have.

results.headline: Heimlich Maneuvers on the Way to Self

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Choke

results.summary_short: To visit the absurdist world of “Choke” requires that you dive through the looking glass into a labyrinth where personal identity is fluid.

results.headline: Into the Mennonite World to Explore One Man’s Test of Faith

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silent Light

results.summary_short: The extravagantly talented director Carlos Reygadas’s immersion in the exotic world of “Silent Light” feels so deep and true that it seems like an act of faith.

results.headline: Slowly, Slowly in the Fog to Noir, via Simenon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Man From London

results.summary_short: “The Man From London,” directed by Bela Tarr, is an outrageously stylized, conceptually demanding film.

results.headline: Triangle With Crude Sides

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Best Friend's Girl

results.summary_short: Kate Hudson loosens her wholesome screen image a notch in her latest star vehicle, a racy comedy, which aims to be tasteless (it often is) and romantic (it mostly isn’t).

results.headline: A City in Flux

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taking Father Home

results.summary_short: “Taking Father Home” is a stunning introduction to a rare new talent.

results.headline: His Task: Help Strangers Die Happily Ever After

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Town

results.summary_short: The sharp comic timing and the offbeat chemistry of Ricky Gervais, Greg Kinnear and Téa Leoni keep “Ghost Town” afloat.

results.headline: When Worlds Collided by Puget Sound

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle in Seattle

results.summary_short: “Battle in Seattle” repeatedly plunges you into the kicking and screaming melee of peaceful protest gone awry.

results.headline: State of the Village

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quilombo Country

results.summary_short: “Quilombo Country” is an up-close-and-personal look at the state of villages throughout Brazil originally founded by insurgent and fugitive slaves.

results.headline: Friends and Family
results.display_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Thousand Years of Good Prayers

results.summary_short: “A Thousand Years of Good Prayers” is a gentle, pleasantly unrushed piece of moviemaking.
